entry.title: Book Censorship Becoming Pointless with e-Readers
entry.content:
Google’s acquisition of Motorola is likely to pay off, with glowing reviews of their new $130 smartphone putting all of their competitors on notice. Last year Nokia announced a $100 Lumia 520 smartphone running Windows phone, and Google and Microsoft are going to continue to try to undercut each other to vie for dominance of the developing market. IDC data indicate that in 2013, the average worldwide price of a smartphone was $337, down from $387 in 2012. With Google using Motorola to dramatically undercut the market prices are likely to fall faster than anticipated, in a move that will be a major win for consumers in developing markets. IDC predicted that the average worldwide smartphone price would fall to $265 by 2017, while the North American average of $531 would rise to $567, but with Google and Microsoft pushing entry level phones I predict it will go down significantly.

Recently, it’s hit the news that parents in an Idaho school district successfully campaigned to remove Sherman Alexie’s acclaimed Young Adult novel, The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian. The multi award winning book was pulled from the shelves after parents objected to its coarse language, references to masturbation, and political criticism of Christian conservatives. Parents called the cops on a student at the high school giving out free copies of the book to peers after the school pulled the book.

The American Library Association has pointed out how farcical censorship is when the #1 most banned book, Captain Underpants, is read by parents to children. The potty humour in the book is designed to make young children giggle and parents roll their eyes. Challenges to the book highlight the absurdity of one group of parents deciding on behalf of every other family in a library district what morals the children are to be raised with.

The National Coalition Against Censorship highlights in their Kids Rights to Read Project that the majority of the most influential books of all time were at one time censored:

The actions of the student in distributing the book, which they love, to younger students in year 10 shows that an intergeneration values disconnect is not going to be solved with parental censorship of the media or libraries, and ultimately highlight why teenagers are justified in abandoning the values of their parents.

Attempts at book censorship are going to become increasingly farcical when technology allows individual consumers to buy books that aren’t stocked in their local library or their local state. 97% of 18-29 year olds use the internet.

2014 figures show that tablet ownership in the US is up to 44% of the adult population, and 50% of adults have either a tablet or an e-reader:

Figures from September 2013 show that 46% of 16-17 year olds have tablets, while 24% have e-book readers. 91% of them have cell phones, while 68% have smartphones.

Smartphones are owned by only 41% of people in with a household income under $30,000 US, rising to 84% of those with household incomes over $150,000. Hopefully with entry level smartphones offering decent performance at US $100, cellphone customers in low income households will move to smartphones in a few years.

One of the other major areas where censorship has played out is in sex education, where conservative states have passed laws banning factual sex education and enforcing ineffectual abstinence-only curricula. With smartphone access to apps by Oregon university and other providers these laws will quickly become redundant, as teens seek out factual, unbiased information online.

Any ideology, political or religious, that requires the censorship of every family within a school district is not going to survive the age of the internet.

entry.title: ultra-leftists
entry.content:
In June 2011 Chip Berlet saw Occupy Wall Street facing a takeover by parasitic sectarian groups, and republished his 1999 essay on cadre ultra-leftist sects. The entire essay is worth a read, here are some highlights:

To describe cadre-based sectarian ultra-leftists as tedious and disruptive is a charitable understatement

Noting the similarity of leftist political division to religious sectarianism:

When a sect tries to enforce these views on everyone, member and non-member alike, the sect [embraces] an inappropriate demand for a mass group to accept uncritically the ideological precepts of a specific group or individual.

On the requirement to toe the party line, ostensibly reached though consultation

Once a specific position is arrived at, cadre are expected to support the decision, and refrain from any disagreement with or criticisms of the “line” with persons or groups outside of the cadre organization. When people talk about “The Party Line,” they mean the line the cadre group members are bound to uphold in public.

Ultra-leftism is an egocentric form of mythopoetic martyrdom whereby practitioners anoint themselves as the beleaguered guardians of the one true political line. They read long impenetrable manifestos at public meetings. They show up at mass demonstrations with helmets and hockey sticks for a game of self-fulfilling prophecy that often results in violence as they hurl themselves at police. They inevitably urge a course of action that is hopelessly out of touch with reality. Even Lenin called this an “infantile disorder.”

The fragmentation of the media environment has attenuated the failure of ultra-leftists to appeal to centrist and soft left voters. Currently the brain drain on twitter is going into overdrive with pepole defending pointless interruption of the ABC’s QandA program

Student protesters interrupt Q&A
A group of rowdy protesters brings the ABC’s Q&A program to an abrupt halt as they chant to interrupt a debate about university funding. Read more: http://ab.co/1kOqUFe

Berlet quotes Andrew Freenberg on how leftist groups prioritise an identity of revolution over effective campaigning:

Sectarianism in the movement was based on a sense of moral superiority that was effective in motivating an in-group but incompatible with its expansion among those sympathetic to its program. Moral heroism mobilized the troops, but it was accompanied by a characteristic romantic elitism rooted in a sense of differentness, of sacrifice and oppression… Many new left groups preferred to substitute individual morality for politics and became obsessively concerned with establishing the revolutionary personal identity of their members at the expense of effective action on the real world.

Some of the social psychologists who’ve studied inter-group conflict and how it applies to politics recommend that people try to reach across party lines to find comonality on key issues, and recognise what their opponents get right. If an asteroid were heading towards earth and was going to destroy the planet, people would instinctively reach across party lines to solve the problem as quickly as possible, rather than trying to boost their poll numbers with divisive rhetoric over the failings of the other side. Jonathan Haidt’s research suggests that Progressives have more work to do than Conservatives in trying to understand the perspective of voters they disagree with.

Bonus - Keating telling whiny protestors to get a job.

‘Go and get a job’ (1995)
Paul Keating is not a fan of student protesters, who should apparently ‘get a job’ and do some work ‘like the rest of us’. More: http://ab.co/keatinginsults

entry.title: Sarah Palin, Anti-Christian
entry.content:
Sarah Palin has joked at an NRA convention that if she was running the country, waterboarding is how she would baptise terrorists. The whole crowd cheered and jeered:

Sarah Palin: If I Were President ‘Waterboarding Is How We’d Baptize Terrorists’
Sarah Palin, former Vice Presidential candidate announced at the National Rifle Association’s “Stand and Fight Rally” on Sunday 4/27/2014 “If I were in charge, they would know that waterboarding is how we baptize terrorists.”

Andrew Sullivan is one of few critics who is willing to stand up and criticise her with the full force she deserves.

Now look how far we have come from the original notion – pioneered by Charles Krauthammer and popularized by “24″ – that torture should only be used in the hypothetical ticking time-bomb case. That argument – only ever hypothetical – nonetheless assumes that torture is evil and should only be used in extremis to prevent imminent catastrophe. Palin, in contrast, like her party, has long since blown past such niceties. She believes that torture should be the first resort – a sign of how America treats its foes, a badge of honor.

What can one say but that this is a bona fide fascistic sentiment. It revels in violence against individuals tied down by their hands and feet and strapped to a terrifying board in order to be suffocated hundreds of times to near-death… Even totalitarian regimes have publicly denied their torture. Their reticence and lies are some small concession of vice to the appearance of virtue. Not Palin – who wants to celebrate brutal torture as the American way.

Sullivan notes that in recent polling on the issue, 62% of White evangelical Christians support torture, while only 40% of religiously unaffiliated Americans do. Support for torture is highest among those who attend church weekly. Torture has become a Christian value in America:

It seems to me, moreover, that torture is a far graver evil, even for orthodox theologians, than non-procreative or non-marital sex. And yet today’s Christianists are obsessed about the latter and not just indifferent to the former, but actually in favor of it. It’s this twisted set of priorities, this exquisitely misplaced set of fears, and this utter ignorance of even basic Christian teaching that reveals all that’s so terribly wrong with American Christianity. It has become its own nemesis.

entry.title: Marketing of euthenasia
entry.content:
Many driving safety advertising campaigns use shocking images of death and disfigurement to drive safely, obey the road rules and put on a seat belt. The ‘embrace life’ campaign has avoided shock and horror and instead opted for a positive message about seatbelts:

Embrace Life - always wear your seat belt
For all licensing and broadcast information visit: http://www.alexandercommercials.co.uk All material © 2010 Sarah Alexander/Daniel Cox/Sussex Safer Roads Partnership. WARNING: All rights of the producer and of the owner of the work reserved. Unauthorised copying, public performance, radio or tv broadcasting of this material is prohibited. Music by Siddhartha Barnhoorn - http://www.sidbarnhoorn.com An original approach to road safety advertising from the Sussex Safer Roads Partnership. http://www.sussexsaferroads.gov.uk Join the Facebook group for Embrace Life at http://www.tinyurl.com/embracetv

People often try to put thoughts of death and suffering out of their minds, as they cause anguish and consternation. Positive messages are more likely to be talked about among families and peer-groups.

The voluntary euthanasia campaign has had verry little success in getting their message across.

Here’s a list of some groups / issues currently out-performing [voluntary euthanasia]:

  • live cattle;
  • puppies born in puppy farms;
  • asylum seekers;
  • transgendered people;
  • homosexuals;
  • the disabled;
  • victims of domestic violence;
  • the corral in the barrier reef;
  • farmers affected by fracking;
  • victims of sexual abuse at the hands of clergy.

These groups are a laundry list of disenfranchised, under-resourced, abused, neglected and unorganised – yet each of them outperform [voluntary euthanasia] week-in, week-out in the battle for media space, barbeque discussions and political response.

The ‘pro-choice’ movement that advocates for a woman’s right to choose abortion (or not) is careful to state that they are not ‘pro-abortion’. They don’t prescribe the circumstances under which they believe a woman should seek an abortion, they leave the choice to the individual. The label ‘Dying with Dignity’ may not be a good name for the voluntary euthanasia movement, and the group ’Doctors for Voluntary Euthanasia Choice’, are approaching a better label.

Death and suffering are taboo because the thought of them cuases distress, so the voluntary euthanasia movement needs to find positive ways to communicate their message. Additionally, the voluntary euthanasia movement has focussed on ultra-leftist audiences to the detriment of broad community outreach.

In 2010 a study of Australian attitudes to abortion, published in the MJA found that contextual details about specific scenarios made people more permissive in their approach to laws:

The sensitivity of Australians’ views on abortion to contextual details may have implications for other debates about ethics. The more permissive attitude elicited when context was provided in our study may, for example, carry over to debates about euthanasia, the use of medicine or technology for human enhancement, organ donation, and embryonic stem cell research. It is an open question whether policy formation should be informed by views about abstract propositions or about cases containing contextual details.

entry.title: The Trolley Problem - Would You Push The Fat Man?
entry.content:
The New York Times has a good discussion of the Trolley Problem

You are walking near a trolley-car track when you notice five people tied to it in a row. The next instant, you see a trolley hurtling toward them, out of control. A signal lever is within your reach; if you pull it, you can divert the runaway trolley down a side track, saving the five — but killing another person, who is tied to that spur. What do you do? Most people say they would pull the lever: Better that one person should die instead of five.

Now, a different scenario. You are on a footbridge overlooking the track, where five people are tied down and the trolley is rushing toward them. There is no spur this time, but near you on the bridge is a chubby man. If you heave him over the side, he will fall on the track and his bulk will stop the trolley. He will die in the process. What do you do? (We presume your own body is too svelte to stop the trolley, should you be considering noble self-sacrifice.)

I loved Jonathan Haidt’s reconciliation of moral psychology with the old philosophical question, and this is an area where a lot of people are turning to hard science to understand ethical reasoning.

Fun facts:

In 1944, new German V-1 rockets started pounding the southern suburbs of London, though they were clearly aimed at more central areas. The British not only let the Germans think the rockets were on target, but used double agents to feed them information suggesting they should adjust their aim even farther south. The government deliberately placed southern suburbanites in danger, but one scientific adviser, whose own family lived in South London, estimated that some 10,000 lives were saved as a result. A still more momentous decision occurred the following year when America dropped atom bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki on the argument that a quick end to the war would save lives — and by macabre coincidence, the Nagasaki bomb was nicknamed Fat Man. Similar calculations are being made right now. One has only to think of collateral damage in military strikes, or of the justifications offered for torturing terrorism suspects. At their best, such reasonings are valid; at their worst, they are a writhing nest of weasels.

If it is considered ethical to select which civilians die in enemy bombings, is it ethical to subject your own soldiers to chemical weapons during tests?

In the early 1940s, medical scientists funded by the U.S. Chemical Warfare Service conducted painful mustard gas experiments on at least 60,000 American soldiers. The Allies, including the governments of Canada, Britain, Australia, and the United States, conducted these experiments on their own soldiers in order to identify the impact of chemical weapons on the health of soldiers.

Many people see this as one of the cases of the long history of morally dubious, and often downright criminal human experiments carried out without informed consent. Nazi scientists during the Nuremberg trials cited American human experiments carried out without the knowledge of prison inmates.

In some areas it’s hard to tell whether the history of abuses of human experimentation is worse in the US or in Nazi Germany, Japan or Russia and North Korea.

Many international critics successfully argue against human rights abuses in other countries, but freqently do so while covering up their own.

entry.title: Why are Australians so Down on Refugees?
entry.content:
Barney Zwartz, retired religion columnist for the Age, has a good piece on the messaging of refugee advocates:

The message was that [refugee advocates] were the compassionate ones, the moral ones, the real Australians. The implication, well-understood and resented by opponents, is that those who disagree with the protesters are selfish, uncaring and/or racist and/or morally torpid…

Stigmatising half the population is no way to persuade people; it is no way to change refugee policy. Nor do I believe it is accurate. How such a large proportion of Australians came to see people fleeing persecution as illegals, queue jumpers, economic migrants, and a threat to our national economy and security is too big a subject to tackle here, but it is the successful result of malign policy and media slanting.

It is quite a complex issue indeed. The Moral Foundations Theory shows that most political arguments touch on six core values:

Care/harm for others, protecting them from harm.
Fairness/cheating, Justice, treating others in proportion to their actions Liberty/oppression, characterizes judgments in terms of whether subjects are tyrannized.
Loyalty/betrayal to your group, family, nation. Authority/subversion for tradition and legitimate authority. Sanctity/degradation, avoiding disgusting things, foods, actions.

Jonathan Haidt, the theory’s author has found that people have strange ideas about the notion of Sanctity. When asked if it’s OK for an old lady to tear up an unwanted national flag to wipe down her toilet bowl, many people are disgusted and outraged, but struggle to say why it’s wrong to use her own property in the privacy of her own home in the way she wishes. The majority of people believe that the flag is a sacred symbol, and indeed the Union Jack is made up of three crucifixes. Many Australians feel a sense of social identity from their belonging to the nation state, and John Howard would not have mandated that every public school must have a national flag in 2004 if it didn’t make for powerful propaganda. When Amanda Bishop and Phil Lloyd satirised the prime minister having sex wrapped in an Australian flag liberals were amused while conservatives were out for blood

Miranda Kerr’s bum received a much warmer reception from conservatives than Amanda Bishop’s

Many racists express a concern that the country is being “polluted” by migrants and their cultural values and religious beleifs. But the vast majority of people do not hold racist sentiments towards immigrants:

More than 60% of us said we wanted immigration to increase or stay the same. In Germany that figure was 22%… For a bunch of racists, we are unusually tolerant.

In 2009 Australia had the highest level of immigration per capita in the OECD, eclipsing influxes that have caused tabloid pandemonium elsewhere. A quarter of us were born overseas, almost half have at least one overseas born parent. Interracial marriage, often identified by demographers as a truer indicator of racism than expressed attitudes, is the norm here. A majority of third generation non-English speaking immigrants intermarry, most to Anglo-Celtic Australians. Our treatment of boat people isn’t just different to how other countries treat refugees. It’s different to how Australians themselves treat immigrants of every other kind.

One of the real issues in modern Australia, however, is that while inner city white collar voters enjoy the benefits of globalisation, outer suburban blue collar workers feel deeply concerned about their jobs going offshore. It’s easier to sell a carbon tax to inner city architects and engineers that design solar panels than to outer suburbs steelworkers and bricklayers that see solar panels manufactured in China and shipped in. Similarly the divide over refugees may not be as much about racism as about class inequality and job security concerns.

So the Moral Foundation of Sanctity can explain racist opposition to immigration, but anyone that doesn’t want the country “polluted” by refugees would feel the same way about migrants. With the opposition to refugees greater than to migrants, there are other issues at play. Security is frequently portrayed as a major issue, and the claim that Australia’s borders and soveringnty must be “protected” is an effective argument about how people don’t want their respect for authority to be subverted by people smugglers.

The fact that Howard used military vessels to intercept the Tampa in the same way that customs vessels would target drug smugglers powerfully shaped Australian perceptions of the “security risk” of asylum seekers. After the September 11th attacks and 2002 Bali Bombings it became harder for liberals to criticise the use of the Australian military to repel the Tampa. Explaining that Hazara muslims are persecuted by Al-Queda, and that Iranians are mostly secularists repressed by a theocratic government has become harder ever since. The claim that asylum seekers are “illegals,” while a blatant lie that has been debunked endlessly, continues to be a powerful tool to elicit the feeling that asylum seekers and people smugglers are subverting Australia’s rules.

Haidt’s analysis shows that Sanctity, Authority and Loyalty are moral foundations that social conservatives prioritise, while Compassion, Fairness and Liberty are principles that liberals prioritise. Libertarian care deeply about limiting the size of government because they prioritise freedom from opression above all other moral foundations. Strongly progressive voters base their moral intuitions on compassion far more than any other moral foundation. Critically, social conservatives do not lack compassion, they just base their moral intuitions on compassion in equal proportion to other foundations.

It’s been well established that compassion is the only moral foundation being advocated by some progressives. Unfortunately, progressive voices articulate a desire for compassion but don’t don’t seem to speak out effectively on how the Australian notion of fairness and egalitarianism is effectively manipulated.

Australia is one of the only countries that links our humanitarian refugee intake to the number of irregular arrivals. The notion that refugees should join a “queue” is a powerful appeal to Australia’s sense of fairness that doesn’t have simple three word slogan answers. In reality, the UNHCR had 7.1 million refugees in 2011 while only 79,800 were resettled, meaning that the UNHCR “queue” may not clear for any one refugee in their lifetime.

There’s so much more to write on when it comes to refugees, but the progressive narrative needs to move away from overrepresenting racism in the Australian community. Malcom Fraser prevented Vietnamese from making risky voyages to Australia by boat by setting up a processing centre in Indonesia that quickly processed asylum seekers and put genuine refugees on a plane to the mainland. With conflicts like Syria, global refugee numbers are not going down, so the issue is going to need more than three word slogans focussed on the current electoral cycle. That will mean having regional resettlement agreements, which can’t effectively be negotiated without bipartisanship, which can’t be achieved without swinging voters on side, which can’t be achieved unless progressive rhetoric changes to inform, rather than castigate political moderates that currently buy into media misrepresentation of the issue.

entry.title: 2013 NSW Crime Figures Released
entry.content:
The NSW Bureau of Crime Statistics And Reporting has released figures from 2013 showing the trends in crime reporting.

This report presents data on crime reported to, or detected by, the NSW Police Force from January 1995 to December 2013, with a focus on the statistical trends for the 24 months ending December 2013. The data were extracted from the Computerised Operational Policing System (COPS) of the NSW Police Force in February 2014.

The report includes an overview of trends in the most recent two-year period for major offence categories, firstly for NSW and then across NSW regions broken down to the Local Government Area (LGA) level. At the State level, for the 24-month period to the end of December 2013 two major offence categories have been trending upwards: indecent assault, act of indecency and other sexual offences (up 7.8%) and fraud (up 13.2%). Seven of the 17 major offence categories were trending downwards: robbery without a weapon (down 11.2%), break and enter dwelling (down 13.3%), break and enter non-dwelling (down 10.5%), motor vehicle theft (down 12.9%), steal from motor vehicle (down 5.0%), steal from person (down 11.8%) and malicious damage to property (down 8.1%).

The NSW graphs for rates of violent and property offences are on page 7 of the report. For violent offences using the 12-month moving average (light grey line) we can see a downward path over the past five years and this can also be seen in the trend tests for the levels of reported offences in Table 1.1. The property offences graph using the 6-month moving average (light grey line) indicates a strong downward path since about 2000 to 2010, after which it stablised before dropping again more recently. Table 1.1 for trend tests on the levels of property offences indicates a stable trend over the last five years, however a significant decrease over the two most recent years.

Interestingly, the largest increase in any crime was in “traffic regulatory offences”, meaning that the NSW government is using mobile speed cameras to issue more tickets to fill state coffers.

entry.title: Eye Tracking Can Predict Political Preferences
entry.content:
Jefferson wrote that “The same political parties which now agitate the United States, have existed through all time.”

Researchers using eye tracking technology have evaluated how much time people look at images within a collage like this one:

Tracking which images you look at can predict your disgust response, and your political preference

Researchers found that the eye tracking predicted the political preferences of the individuals. This suggests that the disgust response is genetically innate to the individual, meaning that political preferences may result from genes. Thus, there will always be liberals and conservatives. Chris Mooney interviewed the main researcher on his results on the Inquiring Minds podcast:

David Pizarro has researched the disgust responses of liberals and conservatives, and evaluated how they relate to views on sexuality:

David Pizarro: The strange politics of disgust
What does a disgusting image have to do with how you vote? Equipped with surveys and experiments, psychologist David Pizarro demonstrates a correlation between sensitivity to disgusting cues – a photo of feces, an unpleasant odor – and moral and political conservatism. It’s Hard to Gross Out a Libertarian: Jonathan Haidt on Sex, Politics, and Disgust
“Morality isn’t just about stealing and killing and honesty, it’s often about menstruation, and food, and who you are having sex with, and how you handle corpses,” says NYU social psychologist Jonathan Haidt, who is author of THE RIGHTEOUS MIND: WHY GOOD PEOPLE ARE DIVIDED BY POLITICS. entry.title: The Need for Public Intellectuals
entry.content:
Chompers noted

“Citizens of the democratic societies should undertake a course of intellectual self defense to protect themselves from manipulation and control, and to lay the basis for meaningful democracy”

Robin writes

Academics used to face a hard choice between writing for sequestered journals that few people read and newspapers and magazines that are hard to break into. Now we have a third option: the blogs and Tumblr, Twitter and Facebook accounts of the social media world.

In my first year out of graduate school, I wrote an article in The American Political Science Review about the politics of fear. I can count on my hand the number of people outside academia who have read it. Not because it’s abstruse or irrelevant but because it’s cloistered behind journal paywalls that only academics can easily scale.

Now I have a blog, where I write about political theory, McCarthyism and bathroom breaks. As many as 20,000 people read my posts — in a single day. Thousands of my colleagues are doing the same thing, many with even bigger readerships. Group blogs such as Crooked Timber and Lawyers, Guns and Money offer platforms to political scientists, economists, sociologists, literary critics, historians and philosophers, and judging by the comments they attract, they are read by a great many nonacademics.

…At their best, intellectuals do more than package their research into digestible bits for policymakers or the public. They force us to think beyond the limits of the day, to ask the questions no one is asking. They are an invitation to imaginative excess and political trespass. Academic experts in the mainstream media reassure us with their authority; young intellectuals in the little magazines arrest us with their divinations.

…Writers and academics who fret over the fate of public intellectuals may think they are debating vital questions of the culture. But their discussions are myopically focused on the writing habits of a rapidly disappearing elite.

Pigliucci has launched Scientia Salon to stimulate discussions among a general audience, noting that pursuit of a eudaimonic life involves reasoned discourse.

3) We acknowledge — as is clear from research in the cognitive sciences — that human beings navigate the world by deploying a complex mixture of reason and emotion, and that they often engage in rationalization more than rationality.

4) Indeed, we think with David Hume that this is a crucial part of human nature, since emotions are necessary in order to actually care about anything in the first place.

5) But we also think that open and reasoned discourse is fundamental for the pursuit of a eudaimonic life on the part of the individual, as well as for the development of a just and democratic society.

6) Scientia, understood as the broadest range of scientific and humanistic disciplines that positively contribute to human understanding, is an essential tool for pursuing that eudaimonic life and achieving that just society.

7) In order to make an impact, we think that writers concerned with these matters ought to aim at a wide audience, avoid unnecessary jargon, and write clearly and engagingly, even humorously when appropriate.

8) We therefore welcome authors and readers who are willing to contribute honestly and substantively to an open dialogue on all matters of the intellect, especially those of general interest to fellow human beings.

entry.title: Is Your Self-Identity Holding You Back?
entry.content:
Paul Graham in 2009 noted that many discussions about religion and politics quickly stir up emotion in people:

As a rule, any mention of religion on an online forum degenerates into a religious argument. Why? Why does this happen with religion and not with Javascript or baking or other topics people talk about on forums?

…Then it struck me: this is the problem with politics too. Politics, like religion, is a topic where there’s no threshold of expertise for expressing an opinion. All you need is strong convictions.

Graham notes that discussions about a Bronze age war rarely devolve to political arguments, whereas modern conflicts that involve citizens of one’s country often do. He concludes:

If people can’t think clearly about anything that has become part of their identity, then all other things being equal, the best plan is to let as few things into your identity as possible.

One of the greatest reasons that humans have dominated the entire planet is our ability to collaborate with non-kin groups. Many people refer to others in the same religion, nationality or political group as their brothers and sisters.

Psychologists have demonstrated cultural polarisation based on the affiliation with social institutions. Kahan writes in Fixing the communications failure:

In a famous 1950s psychology experiment, researchers showed students from two Ivy League colleges a film of an American football game between their schools in which officials made a series of controversial decisions against one side. Asked to make their own assessments, students who attended the offending team’s college reported seeing half as many illegal plays as did students from the opposing institution. Group ties, the researchers concluded, had unconsciously motivated students from both colleges to view the tape in a manner that favoured their own school.

Since then, a growing body of work has suggested that ordinary citizens react to scientific evidence on societal risks in much the same way. People endorse whichever position reinforces their connection to others with whom they share important commitments. As a result, public debate about science is strikingly polarized. The same groups who disagree on ‘cultural issues’ — abortion, same-sex marriage and school prayer — also disagree on whether climate change is real and on whether underground disposal of nuclear waste is safe.

Kahan and his colleagues have identified a range of issues where perceived clashes with cultural values of a particular group polarise opinion.

Some people that retire after working in a job for decades, say as an accountant, will volunteer one day a week for a charity because the question “what do you do?” is often the second thing that people are asked.

Personally, I think that the strength of social identity is a strong reason why the No True Scotsman fallacy frequently comes up in political and religious arguments. It goes like this

Person A: No democracy ever starts a war
Person B: Well country X is a democracy and they started a war
Person A: Well, no true democracy ever starts a war

LessWrong has an article about choosing a small identity to bootstrap a larger worldview. Identities like “growth mindset” or “someone who tries new things” or a “jack of all trades.” Perhaps the best one is “truth-seeker,” which is a more useful mindset to have than any religious or political identity that can lead someone to become closed minded when they perceive a threat to their group’s values.

Studies have found that when a sports fan’s team loses, junk food sales go up. Jonathan Haidt has written about how non-violent sport is probably an outlet for the tribalism we previously needed to survive.

A recent Pew Social Trends study has found that millenials are the generation least inclined to identify with political and religious institutions:

Pew Research Center surveys show that half of Millennials (50%) now describe themselves as political independents and about three-in-ten (29%) say they are not affiliated with any religion. These are at or near the highest levels of political and religious disaffiliation recorded for any generation in the quarter-century that the Pew Research Center has been polling on these topics.

If you identify as a Democrat then you will probably be personally offended when Obama does something that goes against your values (every president will dissapoint their supporter base on some issues), and you’ll probably feel your blood pressure go up every time you see a clip of FOX news. Making matters worse these days, search engines are increasingly using algorithms to return results that are relevant based on previous searches. This means that someone who has spent time searching for political content will get more political content in future internet searches, and someone that reads conservative websites often will find conservative websites in their search results more often.

Bill Maher has explained how people have less in common than they used to, now that people all get customised stories based on what they’ve clicked on in the past:

Bill Maher discovers “The Filter Bubble”
February 21, 2014 Episode 308 Eli Pariser: Beware online “filter bubbles” https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B8ofWFx525s The Filter Bubble: How the hidden web is shaping lives https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6_sim_Wc3mY Additional information: http://www.thefilterbubble.com http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_bubble —– Transcript New Rule: The Sparkletts guy must tell me why nobody talks around the water cooler anymore. But, wait, I think I know why. It’s because as a culture we don’t have enough in common anymore. And that’s because the Internet, which was supposed to unite the world, has become too adept at serving us personalized content. Do you know what I saw on Yahoo’s front page this morning? No, you don’t, because mine isn’t the same as yours. People get newsfeeds now that just spit back customized stories based on what we’ve clicked on in the past. So, I, for example, might see a lot of stories about pot, American history, and, of course “Christian Mingle.” Whereas, Ted Nugent just gets ads for Prozac and bullets. So, yes, welcome to the brave new world of micro-targeting which – look, admittedly is often harmless. No one gets hurt if my computer tells me, “You bought ‘James Taylor’s Greatest Hits.’ You might also enjoy this pillow and these sleeping pills.” Or, “You’ve shown an interest in ‘nipple slips.’ Here’s every picture ever of Tara Reid.” [slide of Tara Reid] “And here’s an article about another slippery boob.” [slide of Ted Cruz] But, consider this: back in the olden days, this is how people spent their time on the subway. [older slide of crowded subway] Amazing, isn’t it? Everyone is reading a newspaper and no one is masturbating. Here’s a subway car today. [three people sit staring at hand-held devices] Everyone is playing “Angry Birds,” and no one is getting news. Or, if they are, it’s their Facebook newsfeed, which is now how a third of their – of adults get their news. And this month, Facebook unveiled an app called “Paper,” which Mark Zuckerberg calls – quote – “the best personalized newspaper in the world.” Yeah, I suppose the Washington Post is okay, like when it uncovered Watergate, but Facebook lets you share pictures of your lunch and do this? [he gestures and makes goofy face] But…but, hey, if one of the richest companies in America can get richer by making you a little stupider every time you look at your phone, small price to pay. And, boy, does it make you stupider. “Paper” tracks the news you’re interested in and gives you more of that and less of everything else, never burdening you with contradictory information or telling you anything new. That’s what makes it news. But, only seeing the stuff that confirms the opinions you already have isn’t news. It’s Fox News. The reason so many Americans, for example, think climate change is a hoax, is that their only source for science news is Glenn Beck, Fox and Matt Drudge, the “cracker trifecta.” Newspapers may be old-fashioned, but here’s what we’re losing if you never see one: they are trying to tell you what’s actually important, not just what’s important to you. You may not read the whole paper, but you at least see headlines making you aware that something’s going on outside of your micro-targeted world of fashion or music or wiccans or zombies or whatever you’re into. I don’t enjoy reading about climate change. It’s depressing. But, for example, I recently saw a headline that said jellyfish are taking over the ocean. Which I found alarming. So, I read the article. And, apparently, yes, jellyfish are the cockroaches of the sea and will happily eat all the toxic shit we’re putting in the ocean which is killing everything else down there. But, the jellyfish are, like, “Oil? Fuckin’ love it!” “Plastic? I had some for lunch.” Yes, jellyfish: 500 million years of yechhh…and now their time has come. [laughter] And, no one is going to hear about it unless a jellyfish washes up on a beach and exposes its nipple. Additional information: http://www.hbo.com/real-time-with-bill-maher#/real-time-with-bill-maher/episodes/12/308-episode/index.html —– Fair Use Notice http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_use The use of the following media materials is protected by the Fair Use Clause of the U.S. Copyright Act of 1976, which allows for the rebroadcast of copyrighted materials for the purpose of commentary, criticism, and education.

Mark Scott, managing director of the ABC, has warned Christians not to get trapped in a bubble:

“The new media environment presents a great risk for Christians to retreat. There will be in a media sense, a massive global market for Christians to listen to Christian music, to read Christian books, to see Christian films, to partake in Christian blogs, to comment on each other’s Christian Facebook pages and to live in that Christian world.

The same can be true for atheists, Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians and everyone else who reads only information that agrees with their preferred label. If a Democrat spends 90% of their time reading websites that have a liberal perspective, then it might be harder for them to empathise with someone who disagrees with their political philosophy, and we see that all the time in snarky comments that seek to dogpile critics rather than address their concerns.

Hume said that truth emerges from arguments between friends, and if you want to find the truth you need to be prepared to listen to people that disagree, and start from the position that you could be wrong. Especially in this day and age of filter bubbles and personalised news feeds, we must be vigilant about how much time we spend cloistered inside media that reflect our own viewpoints, and not be afraid to find dissenting voices. If people constrain themselves to only engaging in discussion with groups of people with the same interests, social capital could go down as we lose the water cooler.

entry.title: Does Frozen Promote Lesbianism and Bestiality?
entry.content:
News outlets all around the world are making fun of a Christian radio host that suggested that the academy award winning film Frozen was inspired by Satan to teach children to embrace lesbianism and bestiality. All while maintaining that he’s not a conspiracy theorist:

TGIF - Frozen promotes lesbianism and bestiality?
The ABC’s TGIF program takes down Swanson’s stupidity.

Does Frozen promote lesbianism and bestiality? No. What it does do is promote that self respect and the resilience to overcome adversity and criticism is a strength in girls. Look at the lyrics for Let it Go:

I don’t care what they’re going to say…
It’s funny how some distance makes everything seem small
And the fears that once controlled me can’t get to me at all
It’s time to see what I can do
To test the limits and break through
No right, no wrong, no rules for me
I’m free…
You’ll never see me cry…

I’m never going back, the past is in the past
Let it go, let it go
And I’ll rise like the break of dawn
Let it go, let it go
That perfect girl is gone
Here I stand in the light of day

The producer noted how they’d departed from the original story to humanise Elsa by making her a sibling of the protagonist):

“Hans Christian Andersen’s original version of The Snow Queen is a pretty dark tale and it doesn’t translate easily into a film. For us the breakthrough came when we tried to give really human qualities to the Snow Queen. When we decided to make the Snow Queen Elsa and our protagonist Anna sisters, that gave a way to relate to the characters in a way that conveyed what each was going through and that would relate for today’s audiences. This film has a lot of complicated characters and complicated relationships in it. There are times when Elsa does villainous things but because you understand where it comes from, from this desire to defend herself, you can always relate to her. ‘Inspired by’ means exactly that. There is snow and there is ice and there is a Queen, but other than that, we depart from it quite a bit. We do try to bring scope and the scale that you would expect but do it in a way that we can understand the characters and relate to them.”

Most critics have hailed the film as promoting self-acceptance and the resilience to overcome bullying and abusive relationships, especially for girls. If hardline radio hosts think that promotes lesbianism, I’d love to see the kind of script that he’d put forward to directors.

Rachel Marie Stone notes how Frozen will help girls overcome purity culture.

entry.title: I read halfway though this article and literally couldn't believe what I was reading... amazing!
entry.content:
As Voltaire once said “The secret of being a bore is to tell everything,” and the secret to a good story is to get the listener to care about the exposition before you reveal the conclusion. Many of the videos that go viral online are professionally produced pieces that fool the viewers into sharing the video with friends without realising that it’s an ad. Recently millions of people shared an artsy black and white video where actors pretended to kiss people for the first time, which was really an ad for a boring clothing company.

Last year Saatchi came up with this piece of slo-mo genius:

First Taste
Tasty video bit at #TEDxSydney 2013. Video by Saatchi & Heckler

Ads that go viral commonly focus on universal human truths that work in any language, on any continent. Many of the popular “best of web” videos focus on stunning nature scenes, slo-mo extreme sports and people with weird dance moves.

The parodies of the first kiss video are many and varied, this one with dogs is one of the stranger ones:

FIRST SNIFF (First Kiss Parody)
We asked some dogs to kiss for the first time…

Vice created a more realistically awkward video by getting 20 strangers who aren’t models to kiss each other. As Vice notes, a growing number of websites are getting better at tweaking algorithms to pump traffic-magnet content like “Half Way Through These Photos, I Could Barely Handle It. But I’m Glad I Made It to the End… Amazing.” As each new meme website tries to game social algorithms by running other people’s content under misleading headlines, more and more stories are just beat-ups created for the online outrage factory. One of the most egregious examples of race baiting is the bogus story that Chinese people are grinding up babies into soup to increase their sexual potency. In the race to reach the lowest common denominator, no barrier is too low for a quick buck.

Vice notes that there was a time when ad agencies veered on the side of overestimating the intelligence of their customer base, which was before the days of social media marketing managers. Just see Corporate Brand(R) on Facebook for fantastic ideas about user engagement. For every retweet that the douchebags get, they’ll even donate up to the fixed amount that they already decided to donate.

Sometimes people make honest mistakes by repeating accidental misquotes, and indeed one of the most famous Voltaire quotes wasn’t his. Others are trying to make money using the internet to peddle bunk that’s been around for centuries:

Derren Brown - Science Of Scams | Brick Breaking
Derren Brown shows us a paranormal trick. SUBSCRIBE. AND LIKE

The full series of the Science of Scams is worth a watch.

entry.title: Tech in Education - Khan Academy to offer SAT prep
entry.content:
The New York Times has some interesting coverage of recent developments in Ed-Tech. One of the big ones is that the US’s SAT system is going to partner with Khan Academy to deliver a classroom-focussed college admissions system, and provide preparation to everyone, rather than just the rich that can afford test prep classes. Free preparation for one of the most important US college admissions tests is a major coup for the organisation that Bill Gates and others have backed to improve the learning quality of students around the world.

Related news:

New All-Digital Curriculums Hope to Ride High-Tech Push in Schoolrooms

English language curriculums built entirely on a digital platform — replacing written textbooks, worksheets or printed study guides — are about to enter the market from several companies, with promises that they will change the nature of classroom learning across the country.

The Obama administration has pledged to provide high-speed Internet connections to 15,000 schools over the next two years, districts are purchasing tablets and laptops for students, and on Friday, President Obama announced $400 million in corporate commitments from the software companies Adobe and Prezi, which will donate software to teachers. Meanwhile, other companies are rushing in.

On Monday at an education conference in Austin, Tex., Joel Klein, the former chancellor of New York City public schools and the current chief executive of Amplify, the education unit of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, will introduce a digital English language arts curriculum for middle school.

Mr. Klein said the new software, which will run on a variety of devices and is priced at $45 per student a year, includes videos, games and vocabulary apps and allows teachers to track student writing and give feedback directly online. “This is not a bunch of souped-up PDFs,” Mr. Klein said, referring to digital versions of print documents.

McGraw Hill, the textbook publisher, will also announce this week that it has signed a partnership with StudySync, a company that creates digital English curriculum tools that have been deployed in 22,000 classrooms and are priced at about a third of Amplify’s rate.

No Child Left Untableted

The key, he said, is personalized learning — breaking free of the mass-production model, tailoring the curriculum to the student and redesigning it around proven competence rather than accrued face time, so that each student can go at his own pace. “Now your job is not to dispense knowledge,” Britt told the trainees. “It’s to facilitate learning. No longer is the teacher the bottleneck between students and knowledge. Rather, the teacher architects the environment — in the classroom, on the tablet, online, everywhere.”

Textbook efficiency:

When I asked Arne Duncan, the U. S. secretary of education, about the increasing amounts of money being spent by school systems on educational technology, he said: “We spend precious taxpayer money now on textbooks, buses, milk, all kinds of things. The real question is, ‘How do you spend more effectively?’ ” Electronic readers could make textbooks better and cheaper, he said. “As a country we spend $7 billion to $8 billion a year on textbooks. My simple question is, ‘Why?’ ” Referring to the six-year textbook-adoption cycle some states still use, Duncan said, “That’s a Neanderthal system.”

GigaOm has a good take on the design of Khan Academy

Since its founding in 2008 by former hedge fund analyst Salman Khan — who was making math videos in his spare time to tutor his cousins — Khan Academy has emerged as a new way to learn; one that is self paced, approachable, conversational and tries to help students master individual subjects before moving onto the next. Bill Gates is a big fan, as is Google and its chairman Eric Schmidt as well as Netflix CEO Reed Hastings — all of these big names invested in the company.

While millions of users access the site and watch its content, 30,000 classrooms also use the videos for in-school teaching and teachers (they call them coaches) can also use the software to track student progress. All of these moving parts are tied together by an understated design ethos that highlights simplicity, puts the content first, and tries remove frustration and friction from learning.

Audrey Watters has a good roundup of the politics of the “Open” label being applied beyond open source tech, especially in Ed-Tech where “open” online courses more commonly means ”open for business”. She has an extensive discussion of MOOC hype in a 2013 rundown that is well worth a read.

entry.title: Customs Propaganda Broadcasts Suffering in Immigration Detention
entry.content:
Government propagandists for Customs are now broadacasting that asylum seekers will suffer physical and mental harm in detention camps:

The Australian public is being kept in the dark like never before about the number of boat arrivals and the conditions of the detention camps. The public is allowed to know that the camps cost $1.5 billion each year to operate, but the government has effectively denied Australian journalists any real coverage of the conditions in the camps. The politically motivated expulsion of a judge from Nauru before an inquiry into their detention camps is another way in which secrecy is being maintained.

The Abbott government claims that they have a mandate to “stop the boats.” It’s unclear if the people that gave them that mandate understand what is happening with their money, in their name.

Some Myths debunked by the Refugee Council:

Myth: Refugees can receive social security payments simply because they are refugees. Fact: Refugees receive the same social security benefits as everyone else. Myth: Refugees living in Australia receives a larger weekly allowance from Centrelink than age pensioners. Fact: A single person with no dependent children applying for the Newstart Allowance (whether or not he or she is a refugee) receives over $200.00 LESS per fortnight than a single age pensioner. Myth: Refugees receive higher rates of payment under Centrelink programs than other Australians. Fact: Centrelink payments are calculated at exactly the same rate for both refugees and non-refugees. Myth: Asylum seekers can receive Centrelink payments. Fact: Asylum seekers are not entitled to the same forms of financial support as citizens or permanent residents. Myth: Illegal immigrants can receive Centrelink payments. Fact: Only Australian citizens and permanent residents can receive social security payments from Centrelink and illegal immigrants are certainly not entitled to such support. Myth: “If you cross the Afghan border illegally, you get shot” (and so on). Fact: The list of penalties for illegally crossing the border has been fabricated and has no basis in law. Myth: Asylum seekers who cross national borders without valid papers are breaking the law. Fact: Asylum seekers do not break any Australian laws simply by arriving on boats or without authorisation. Myth: Asylum seekers, upon their arrival in Australia, are “given” a job, an interpreter, a driver’s license, a social security number, welfare payments and credit cards. Fact: Asylum seekers are not automatically “given” any of these things upon arrival. Myth: Refugees and asylum seekers receive higher rates of payment under Centrelink programs than age pensioners or other Australians. Fact: Centrelink payments are calculated at exactly the same rate for both refugees and non-refugees. Myth: This e-mail has been endorsed by Mr Maurice Kriss, a Sydney-based Barrister at Law. Fact: This e-mail has not been endorsed by Mr Kriss. Myth: Refugees and asylum seekers receive “all expenses paid” accommodation in Australia. Fact: Refugees and asylum seekers do not receive free accommodation. Myth: Refugees and asylum seekers receive cash benefits starting at $800.00 per week. Fact: A refugee who has permanent residency in Australia is entitled to exactly the same social security benefits as any Australian citizen or permanent resident in the same circumstances - which are nowhere near $800.00 per week. Myth: Anyone can seek asylum, provided they don’t hold a valid Australian Passport. Fact: Anyone can seek asylum, regardless of their nationality. Myth: No asylum application is ever refused, reasonable or unreasonable. Fact: Asylum applications are frequently refused. Myth: Immigration detention facilities, such as the facility on Christmas Island, are comparable to luxury hotels or holiday resorts. Fact: High-security immigration detention centres are comparable to prisons, with the Christmas Island facility being one of the worst examples. Conditions in hotels used as “alternative places of detention” can hardly be described as luxurious. Myth: Terrorists, drug smugglers, mass murderers and other criminals can be granted refugee status. Fact: Providing asylum is not about harbouring criminals – it is about protecting people from persecution. Myth: Refugees are “lucky winners in the easiest game on earth”. Fact: It is outrageous to claim that refugees are “lucky” people who have been through an “easy” experience. Myth: All of the detainees at the Scherger detention centre are being accepted into Australia. Fact: It is not possible to make this claim because applications of the detainees at Scherger are still being assessed. Myth: Asylum seekers in detention receive a pension and hardship allowance, the sum of which is double the amount received by age pensioners. Fact: Asylum seekers in detention do not receive any form of financial assistance. Myth: Asylum seekers in detention receive $50.00 a day for spending money. Fact: Detainees in the Scherger facility do not receive cash payments. Myth: One quarter of a tonne of chicken a day alone is cooked at the Scherger Detention Centre. Fact: This claim is false. Myth: Detainees at the Scherger detention centre refuse to pick up their own rubbish and there have been “massive disputes” because detainees “didn’t like the radio station” and “batteries were flat for the Nintendo games.” Fact: These claims are false.

Bill Nye recently debated the world’s leading apologist for Young Earth Creationism, Ken Ham. Ham believes that nothing can ever dispove a 6,000 year old earth, and that unicorns are real animals. Many atheists and scientists opposed the debate, as they were concerned it would legitimise pseudoscience as worthy of scientific consideration, and give money to Ham to build his full scale “replica” of the ark. After the event most commentators decided that Ham shot himself in the foot by relying on the bible, but admitting that his beliefs will never change:

Ken Ham Defeats Himself In 90 Seconds
Did you guys see the debate between Bill Nye VS Ken Ham? Bill Nye did not even need to show up because Ken Ham was nice enough to totally defeat himself in humiliating fashion. If you enjoy my work. Please consider picking up a T-shirt from http://www.cultofdusty.com . Not only do you get an awesome atheist shirt but the support is the only reason new content is able to be made. Thanks guys.

Ken Ham admitted that creationism was not a scientific position by conceding that it had never made any predictions about the natural world, and it isn’t falsifiable. 92% of respondents on a poll in ChristianityToday thought that Bill Nye won the debate, and Pat Robertson said that the idea that “it all came about in 6,000 years is nonsense” and “let’s not make a joke of ourselves”

http://www.rightwingwatch.org/content/even-pat-robertson-thinks-young-earth-creationism-joke Right Wing Watch reports on the extreme rhetoric and activities of key right-wing figures and organizations by showing their views in their own words. In this video, Pat Robertson says he disagrees with Young Earth Creationism and considers it a “joke.”

Slate notes that HBO is airing a documentary about the rise of creationism in America, with the following quote from a pastor:

“If somewhere in the Bible I were to find a passage that says two plus two equals five,” the pastor states plainly, “I wouldn’t question what I’m reading in the Bible. I would believe it—accept it as true and then do my best to work it out and to understand it.”

The problem is that the bible asks belivers to think that pi is 3 in 1 Kings:

And he made a molten sea, ten cubits from the one brim to the other: it was round all about, and his height was five cubits: and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.

Biblical literalists have a range of bogus explanations for why these numbers are true, without embracing the idea that mathematics is wrong. We don’t call someone a theistic mathematician if they believe in the accuracy of pi, or a theistic meteorologist if they believe rain comes from clouds rather than storehouses in heaven. The mythical beasts that were included in the King James Bible, like Satyrs, Unicorns and Cockatrices have mostly been retranslated in modern bibles. It was said in relation to the Nephilim that ”There’s a sucker born every minute” and most people find the mythical creatures laughable:

Other than the occasional hick, nobody challenges the heliocentric model, and the flat earth society seems to have fallen over the edge of the disc. Other than Phil Plait, nobody decries the spherist bias in the media. Evolution is one of the only areas where children are encouraged to disrupt their science classes, and United States legislatures are trying to encourage the teaching of nonsense. Creationists have managed to get hundreds of millions of dollars in federal funding in Australia to persue their secterian agenda, and are set to introduce creationism as an “alternate perspective” into the history curriculum during the national curriculum review.

Bill Nye’s biggest appeal in his debate was that for Western countries to be globally competitive in the 21st century, we need to empower science educators to give children a love of learning that will prepare them to be innovators in the rapidly changing technology sector. Religiously and politically motivated campaigns instead want to cast doubt about scientific consensus on topics like evolution and climate change, and are well financed to do so. Anyone with a love of science needs to fight the underhanded campaigns that are trying undermine science education in school classrooms.

entry.title: Youth Perspectives on Tech in Schools: From Mobile Devices to Restrictions and Monitoring
entry.content:
Interesting report on SSRN on the use of tech in schoos, and the youth perspectives on network restrictions and monitoring. Students expressed frustration at the top down focus on technology; “while many participants reported positive feelings around the current state of technology in their schools, some students seemed frustrated about ongoing initiatives to provide them with tablets for academic purposes. Several participants stated that they would have preferred new laptops to new tablets.” Some students expressed frustration at inequalities between the ICT resources of different schools.

78% of young people now have a cell phone, and almost half (47%) of those own smartphones. A large number of students refuse to hand in their devices, even though they don’t plan to use them in school hours. A number of students felt frustrated at the disconnect between ICT policy and the concept of the school trusting their students. Some students use Wifi networks from neighbouring buildings because of speed constraints, and blocking of websites that have information on news topics like rapes in India. The schools need to follow Children’s Internet Protection Act (CIPA) guidelines, which don’t include the blocking of social media sites, even though most schools include it. More public schools than private schools block sites like youtube, which has both “distracting” and objectionable content, as well as educational content. Some students found that blocking Facebook blocked educational sites like Khan Academy that use OAuth to login. Students that saved homework on personal email accounts weren’t able to access them from some school networks.

37% of students admit to bypassing filtering themselves, with simple workarounds like SSL/TLS sites allowed. Some students use VPNs on their own devices. Blocking encrypted tunneling is beyond most school ICT administrators, and there’s a growing recognition that censorship in institutions like public libraries is ineffective and curtails free speech. In a telling statement, one student reveals that teachers sometimes ask their students how to bypass filters.

One of the most problematic issues in the paper is the privacy issue. Schools have legitimate reasons to use screen sharing tools to prevent disruptive behaviour, but this also gives teachers mostly unaccountable access to record private student communications. Most of the privacy protections are in school policy, rather than in the technology itself.

Students have a range of legitimate reasons to bypass censorship, and legitimate concerns around their own privacy. Schools have opened up as a new front in the classic war of users vs owners. The shift from from centrally controlled mainframes to user centric PC’s brought a raft of security issues before some smartphone and tablet vendors moved to a walled garden approach.

ITU figures show that mobile broadband subscriptions are one of the fastest growing sectors in telecomms:

It seems like the only way to be sure that your kid is getting the full educational benefit of the internet without being monitored is to buy them a mobile broadband subscription and send them to a private school. And then ask yourself why on earth we have a digital divide.
